newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy army cleared of widespread abuse in Somalia.
newsitem.headline: Italy army cleared of widespread abuse in Somalia.

text.p: Italy confirmed on Friday that its soldiers tortured Somalis while on a peacekeeping mission in the African state, but an official report said the abuses were not widespread and senior army officers were largely blameless.

The findings were greeted with relief by the army, whose reputation was on the line following accusations that Italian troops committed gross human rights violations while serving in a U.S.-led humanitarian mission to Somalia from 1992 to 1994.
However, local Somali associations blasted the 46-page report as a shameful whitewash. The document was prepared by a five-member commission which included two women and two generals.

The commission, headed by Ettore Gallo, a former president of Italy's Constitutional Court, was set up in June after the press printed detailed allegations that soldiers had raped, tortured and murdered Somalis.
While the report urged improved training and communication within the army, Gallo said the military as a whole had acquitted itself with honour in difficult circumstances.
"I'm proud to say that our Italian soldiers always gave precedence to the humanitarian nature of the mission...and in this respect was the best force (in Somalia)," Gallo told a news conference.
Two generals who led the Italian forces to Somalia resigned in June when the allegations surfaced, but Gallo said generals Bruno Loi and Carmine Fiore could not be held responsible.
"How can the head of the whole operation know what every junior officer is up to?" he asked.
The army association Cocer demanded the men's reinstatement.
"This report does justice to the army and its operations, which are professional and carry out a service for the country," Cocer chairman, Colonel Ettore Cozzi, told reporters.

By contrast, the head of the Somali community in Italy branded the report scandalous. "It has buried everything. It was a hurried inquiry, which has absolved leaders, generals and commanders," Fatuma Hagi Yassin told reporters. "It's shameful".

The commission, which interviewed 145 people and travelled to Africa to meet witnesses, dismissed certain charges against the army, including an allegation that a senior Italian officer had raped and murdered a small boy.
But it said some claims were credible, such as the torture of a Somali youth with electrodes and the sexual abuse of a woman with a stick of explosive.
"If she had been Italian or French or German this would not have happened," Gallo said.
The report added that a lack of discipline meant that drugs and prostitutes had circulated freely in some quarters.
It suggested that in future magistrates and human-rights experts should travel with soldiers on peacekeeping missions to guarantee international law was upheld.
But it also noted that the Somalia operation, code-named "Restore Hope", was not the genuine peacekeeping mission that the Italians had hoped for.
"Instead (soldiers) were suddenly caught up in a repressive policy which they never believed in and which exposed them to grave risks," the commission wrote.

The Somali operation, authorised by the United Nations, was intended to bring food relief to the east African country, but the multinational force rapidly got drawn into a vicious conflict with Somali warlords.
